sect1.title: Getting upwatch
sect1.para: Currently, upwatch is not released, and is not allowed to be distributed. The only way to get it, is through written permission of UpWatch BV.
If you aquired that, you will either receive access to CVS, or will receive a tar.gz file, or .RPM's.

sect2.title: Build requirements
sect2.para: Of course you can build the software yourself. Apart from the normal GNU compilation tools, and the aforementioned packages, you'll need the following on your system to build upwatch:

listitem.para: RPM tools, if you want to build RPM's

sect2.para: If you run redhat, debian or SuSe, don't forget to install the devel packages if there are any.

sect1.title: Compiling upwatch
sect1.para: Just in case you really want to (or need to) compile upwatch yourself, it's pretty easy:
sect1.literallayout: $ tar xzvf upwatch-x.x.tar.gz $ cd upwatch-x.x $ ./configure $ make
sect1.para: Nothing to it... In case of problems, you're probably missing some library or header files, or they are in unexpected places. Look in config.log.

sect1.title: Actual Installation
sect1.para: Before you install the software decide on the architecture. If you know in advance you'll have to monitor thousands of hosts, or the probes will exhaust your machine otherwise, you may have to split your installation across several machines. There may be more reasons to do that. Consult Scaling up and How it all works
For simplicity we assume you run everything on the same host. In this case just install all rpm's on this host. What if you can't use RPM's? Then follow the following procedure as root:
sect1.literallayout: $ mkdir /etc/upwatch.d $ cp config/upwatch.conf /etc $ for i in uw_* > do > cp $i/$i /usr/sbin > cp $i/$i.conf /etc/upwatch.d > done $ for i in uw_send uw_process uw_notify uw_traceroute > do > mkdir -p /var/spool/upwatch/$i/tmp > mkdir -p /var/spool/upwatch/$i/new > done

sect1.title: PHP pages
sect1.para: The PHP pages can just be copied to any directory. There is an include directory. Copy that a some location ouside the web root, and enter its location in the .htaccess file in the web root dir.

sect1.title: Securiy considerations
sect1.para: All of upwatch can be run as a non-root user, except the probes which need root-access, most notable, uw_ping. You can assign each probe its own user and grant that user access rights to its own database tables. The probes only read from the pr_xxx_def and the server tables.
The PHP web user should have SELECT, UPDATE, DELETE access to all tables.

uw_access is the program most vulnerable to crackers, as it waits for incoming connections on a TCP port (1985). If possible, use chroot and firewall rules to limit connections to real probes only. Something similar holds for mysql.Most probes will want access, and passwords can be sniffed. For real security use ssh-tunnels.

sect1.title: Database
sect1.para: Create the database as follows. We assume you have a root password set for mysql:
sect1.literallayout: $ mysqladmin -u root --password=PASSWORD create upwatch $ mysql -u root --password=PASSWORD < upwatch.mysql
sect1.para: Of course you need to assign users and GRANT them access. Note that mosts probes will want read access to their definition table and the server list. In many situations you can use just one user for that. Give that user access with:
sect1.literallayout: $ mysql -u root --PASSWORD=PASSWORD mysql mysql> GRANT SELECT ON upwatch.pr_ping_def TO user@'192.168.170.23' IDENTIFIED BY 'PASSWD' mysql> GRANT SELECT ON upwatch.server TO user@'192.168.170.23' IDENTIFIED BY 'PASSWD'
